I. KEYOBJECTIVESOFTHEGOVERNMENT'SPROGRAMTOLIQUIDATE BANRURALAND CREATEFINANCIERARURAL
1. The broader policy objective ofthis loan is to support an important stage o f the reform o f Mexico's development banking sector. Specifically, this loan supports the liquidation o f Banrural, a Government owned development bank, and the creation, in its place, o f the new Financiera Rural (FR), a non-banking decentralized institution in charge o f promoting the development o f rural financial markets. FR cannot mobilize deposits or issue debt. It is funded directly through budgetary allocations, must maintain the value o f its capital endowment inreal terms, report periodically to Congress, lend only to low and middle income rural producers, and move, over time, fully to second-tier lending.
2. Since the mid-1980s, the Mexican Government has adopted measures to reform state- owned financial institutions. In 1986, the Government approved Organic Laws (Charters) for all development banks, creating a new charter: Sociedad Nacional de Cre`dito. The process o f financial sector reform also involved modifications to risk classification and provisioning rules for development bank loans (May 1993) and capitalizationrules (July 1994). The Tequila crisis prompted the liquidation o f two development banks and induced the government to initiate restructuring plans for the development bankingsystem. More recently, the National Programto Finance Development (PRONAFIDE) for 2002-2006, calls for the modernization o f development banks to help achieve the social and economic goals presented in the National Development Plan.
3. The Government's efforts to reform the development banks are in line with the recommendations o fthe FSAPcarried out inmid-2001. These efforts focus on three areas:
0 Legal and institutional reforms to promote and strengthen non-bank financial intermediaries and popular banking. These reforms include: (i) enactment o f the Law o f Savings and Popular Credit (LACP) and amendment to the General Law o f Organizations and Auxiliary Credit Activities and to the General Law o f Cooperatives; (ii) increation, April 2001,ofthe National FinancialServices Bank (BANSEFI)to promote savings from among low-income populations and promote the development o f savings and credit institutions; (iii)creation, in mid-2001, o f the National Mortgage Bank (Sociedad Hipotecaria Federal- SHF) a development bank for housing finance; and (iv) development, in late 2002, o f FIRA's (Agricultural Related Trust Fund) program to lend through special purpose finance companies.
0 Legal and regulatory reforms to improve the governance and accountabilitv o f development banks. Between 2000 and 2002, reforms were introduced to subject development banks to the same regulation and supervision as commercial banks. These  reforms also aim at promoting the operational efficiency and cost effectiveness of development banks, and limit the losses that they may cause to the Treasury.
0 Restructuring o f development banks. The restructuring emphasized their role of development agencies in charge of developing the financial markets in areas not well covered by the private banks. As development agencies, these institutions are funded directly through the budget, ceasing to take deposits from, and issue debt to the public. Their lending activities are (over time in some cases) limited to second-tier lending through banks and non-bank financial intermediaries, and their capacity to provide subsidies is limited, makingthose that they provide more targeted andtransparent.
4. These reforms set the basis for a more efficient and transparent development banking sector, and go a long way towards reducing the problems associated with direct government intervention inthe banking sector such as lack o f transparency inthe allocation of subsidies, high hidden fiscal costs, and negative incentives for private providers o f financial services. Within this framework, the Government o f Mexico decided to close Banrural, which was the public bank that generates the largest fiscal losses, and create inits place Financiera Rural.
11. PROGRESSINIMPLEMENTINGTHE GOVERNMENT'SPROGRAM

Assets transferred to FR amount to MXP2.108 billion o f credit portfolio and MXP240.3 million o f fixed assets. Banrural's residual assets remain in a fbnd administered by SAR, an agency in charge o f the liquidation o f public asset, for their liquidation. The deposit accounts in Banrural have been transferred to BANSEFI. 0 FR's Board o f Directors (Organo de Gobierno) approved a Strategic Statement (Programa Institucional) outlining mission and objectives, target markets and clients, instruments for providing credit, promoting investment and providing technical assistance, and a policy o f limited credit expansion (no more than 10 percent) in the first year o f operations with respect to the level o f lending provided by B a m r a l in 2002. 0 FR submitted to the Bank a financial projections model o f its operations, agreed to with the Bank. The model included pro-forma balance sheets and income statements.

111. ACTIONS TAKEN TO FULFILLTHE THIRD TRANCHE RELEASE CONDITIONS
A. SatisfactoryProgressin carryingout the Program
Loan Agreement, Article 11, Section 2.02 (f) (i):Bank to be satisfied, based on evidence satisfactory to the Bank, with the progress achieved in the carrying out of the Program.
6. This conditionhasbeen met. The Bankreceived a letter of Sector DevelopmentPolicy, signed by the Subsecretary o f Finance and Public Credit, dated May 9, 2003 describing the strategy that the Government i s following for the restructuring o f its development banks, with particular focus on the liquidation o f Banrural and the creation o f FR. The Letter indicates the commitment o fthe Government to:
0 Require FR to implement interest rate policies congruent with the objective o f financial sustainability requiredby its Charter. To this objective, the authorities are adjusting the interest rates charged by FIRA to avoid creating incentives for interest rate arbitrage among clients that are commonto both institutions; and 0 Provide, ifrequired inthe short term, and for a limitedperiod o f time, budgetary support to cover part o f FR's operating costs to allow it to lend at low but close to market interest
3  rates to its lower income clients. Interest rates charged by FR should always cover the fundingcosts and the risk ofthe operation avoidingmarketdistortions.
7. After two years o f operation, FR represents 15 percent o f the formal credit to rural producers in Mexico. By June 2005, FR had placed 262,051 loans for MXP16.6 billion, about 105 percent o f its original lending fund. Most o f the loans have beento producers with incomes lower than MXP140,OOO. As o f that date, the credit portfolio amounted to MXP8.657 billion, an increase o f 194 percent with respect to December 2003. The average loan size is MXP62,000, equivalent to the financing neededto cover aproducer with 9 hr.o f corn.
8. FR has also made progress towards its objective of developing rural financial intermediaries (RFIs). It has provided 763 loans through RFIs for MXPl.452 billion, equivalent to 8.75 percent o f FR's credits. It has authorized resources to 37 RFIs and offered services for the establishment o f29 other RFIs.
9. The evidence indicates that, while FR continues to rely on subsidies to provide credit to rural markets, it functions with much greater discipline than its predecessor, Banrural. This has beenthe result o fboth intelligent design -constraining its funding activities to the budget- and the hiring of competent personnel. The management is developing systems that eventually should lead to market pricing for at least some o f the credit going to the rural sector. The ability o f the institution to satisfy the thrd tranche condition o f zero net income i s partially due to favorable economic circumstances, but this inno way diminishes the improvement that FR has made to the approach to servicing rural marketsinMexico
B. MacroeconomicPerformance
Loan Agreement, Article 11, Section 2.02 (0 (ii):Bank to be satisfied, based on evidence satisfactory to the Bank, that the macroeconomic policy framework is satisfactory.
10. This condition has been met. The Mexican economy has gained momentum by takmg advantage o f the global economic recovery and high international oil prices. Despite a strong rebound o f economic activity in 2004-when GDP rose 4.4 percent. With growth rate o f 2.8 percent during the first half o f the year, more moderate expansion i s expected in 2005. The global economic recovery, high oil prices and export revenues, favorable external financial conditions, and increased domestic credit, have stimulated aggregate demand in all o f its major categories-private consumption, investment, exports-raising economic activity and employment.
11. Inflation i s moving toward the central bank's mediumterm target of 3 percent. Headline inflation has come down to 3.5 percent by September 2005, after a surge in 2004, largely attributed to some supply-side factors. In order to avoid a spill-over o f these inflationary pressures into price expectations, monetary policy was tightened between early 2004 and mid- 2005. As a result, short-term interest rates increased significantly -by 530 basis points since the low reached in August 2003. Following the successful reduction o f inflation and inflationary expectations, the central bank has recentlyinitiateda cautious relaxationofmonetarypolicy.
4  12. The government has kept the deficit within its annual budget targets and in line with its medium-term goal of fiscal consolidation. Higher than budgeted oil revenue has played an important role in achieving fiscal targets, compensating for lower tax revenue and higher public investment and revenue sharing with state and municipal governments. Oil-related budget revenue has grown by a total o f almost 2.5 percentage points o f GDP over the past three years, allowing the budget deficit to be cut by almost halfthat amount.
13. The government's medium-term fiscal framework aims to further increase fiscal consolidation and reduce public debt. The government's 2006 budget, presented in September, updated its medium-term fiscal projections for 2006-09. The projections include ambitious targets on the budget balance, with a small surplus in 2006, and a drop in off-budget financing. The fiscal consolidation envisaged inthis framework would reduce net augmented debt to about 32 percent o f GDP by 2009, from 41 percent in2004.
14. Price stability, public debt management and policies aimed at financial sector development are leading to a steady growth o f domestic financial savings, whereas fiscal consolidation reduces the claim of the public sector on those savings thereby allowing for a sound expansion in domestic credit to the private sector. Since mid-2003, for the first time since the 1995 bankingcrisis, commercial banks' outstanding credit to the private sector has grown in real terms, thereby strengtheningdomestic sources o f growth.
15. On November 9, 2005, the Executive Board of the IMF concluded the Article IV consultation with Mexico. Directors commended the authorities for improvements they have made in economic policies, institutions and structures over the last decade, which have contributed to greater macroeconomic stability and reduced financial vulnerability. Fiscalpolicy has earned broad credibility, with a track record o f achieving the annual deficit targets and a prudent monetary policy has established a low-inflation environment. A series o f reforms has strengthened the financial sector and boosted its development. Directors welcomed that economic policy making i s taking place in a setting o greater inclusiveness and transparency in government. The challenge ahead will be t launch a new round o f structural reforms that will enhance the economy's efficiency and competitiveness and ensure the transition to a more rapid growth path, while entrenching the considerable progress that has already been made in economic policy design and implementation.

Financiera Rural has submittedto the Bank copy o f the Report Presented by Financiera Rural to Congress in June 2005 under Article 48 fraction I11 o f the Financiera Law. This report i s presented to Congress in April and June o f each year. Section 1 o f this report deals with FR's credit, guarantees, transfers and subsidies programs, and Section 2 deals with FR's compliance with the NationalDevelopment Plan. The report indicates that in the 2005 budget, Congress approved MXP397.1 million pesos in subsidies from the Federal Government for the Program to Facilitate Access to Rural Credit for lower income producers, administered by Financiera Rural. These hnds had been assigned to SAGARPA (MinistryofAgriculture) inthe past andwere transfer to FRin2005 as an offbalance item.
18. The subsidies approved in the 2005 budget were assigned to the following programs: (a) Reduction o f Cost o f Access to Credit, MXP123.8 million; (b) Liquid Guarantees, MXP99.3 million; (c) Promotion and Supervision o f Credit Operations, MXP74.5 million; and (d) Training and Organization, MXP99.5 million. Programs (a) and (b) are designed to facilitate access to credit to lower incomerural producers. 19. This condition has been met. FR has submitted its financial statements for December 2004 and October 2005. These financial statements show a breakdown o f FR's costs o f lending andnonlending activities. The balance sheet figures show that as of October 2005, 50.5 percent o f FR's net assets were invested in securities and 46.9 percent in net loans. Non-performing loans to gross loans are 2.6 percent and, with provisions equal to 7.1 percent o f gross loans, the coverage ratio o f provisions to non-performing loans is almost 3 times. Between year-end 2004 and October 31,2005, the net loan volume o fFRincreased 33.3 percent.
20. FR's income statement figures discriminate between: (i) operational income and expenses resulting from lending operations; and (ii) non-operational income and expenses resulting from training and technical assistance to borrowers and to mutual credit institutions and cooperatives serving rural areas. The figures show that for the first ten months o f 2005, operational results related to lending were positive (MXP 597 million) and negative in 2004, while the non- operational income and expenses had a negative result o f MXP-132 million. Despite the losses
6  in the non-lending operations, the total net result for October 2005 was positive: MXP 465 million.
21. The main reason for the positive operational result was the improvement inthe financial marginin2005, which increased from 3.4 percent o f assets in2004 to 9.2 percent (annualized) in October 2005. The financial margin increased because interest revenue to assets increased by 265 basis points while interest expense - that is, the inflationrate - declined by 310 basis points. The increase in interest revenue was driven by an increase in the government funding rate from an average o f 6.6 percent in 2004 to 9.10 percent in the first six months o f 2005. The average annualized return on loans increased by 110 basis points between 2004 and the first six months o f 2005 (from 11.6 percent to 12.5 percent), while the average return on securities increased by an even greater 250 basis points (from 7.2 percent to 9.8 percent). Incontrast, the inflation rate, which is the funding cost o f the capital endowment, declined from an annual average o f 4.9 percent in2004 to an annualized rate o f 2.1 percent for the first ten months o f 2005.

25. The information provided by the MIS meets four basic parameters o f quality, opportunity, amount and relevance. It has allowed the homologation o f criteria to measure the information, and the centralization and simplification o f the access to the information. Inthe medium term, the MIS will be further developed to meet other criteria established in the Strategic Plan such as the capacity to assess the profitability o feachbusiness center to establish a strategy o f redeployment or closure o f branches. The MIS will also allow FR to determine which markets and customers are capable o f borrowing at market rates, which will lead to the improvement o f the efficiency o f rural credit markets. Moreover, as the information on credit quality i s refined, FRintends to securitize some loans and free resources to expand its lending.
IV. CONCLUSION
26. All the conditions under the Loan Agreement for the release of this third tranche have been met. Based on this assessment the Bank has advised the Government o f Mexico of the availability o f the Third Tranche o fthe Loan for US$l50million.

doc.abstracts: The Rural Finance Development Structural Adjustment Loan for Mexico will support an important stage of the reform of Mexico's development banking sector. Specifically, this loan supports the liquidation of Banrural, a Government owned development bank, and the creation, in its place, of the new Financiera Rural (FR), a non-banking decentralized institution in charge of promoting the development of rural financial markets. FR cannot mobilize deposits or issue debt. It is funded directly through budgetary allocations, must maintain the value of its capital endowment in real terms, report periodically to Congress, lend only to low and middle income rural producers, and move, over time, fully to second-tier lending. All the conditions under the Loan Agreement for the release of this third tranche have been met. Based on this assessment the Bank has advised the Government of Mexico of the availability of the third tranche of the loan for US$l50 million.
